content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy that maximizes my earnings over the long term, considering the 75 rounds of the game.

If we calculate the average payoff for each strategy, it becomes clear that B is not a profitable strategy in the long run. This is because every time I choose R and they choose B, I lose money (0$ vs 40$), but when I choose B and they choose R, I gain less than what they get (40$ vs 45$). So, on average, I lose money with strategy B.

On the other hand, if I play strategy R, I earn 45$ every time my opponent chooses R, and 0$ when they choose B. The average payoff from playing R can be calculated as follows:

Payoff from playing R when opponent plays R = 45$ (occurring 25 times if the opponent also plays R 50% of the time)
Payoff from playing R when opponent plays B = 0$ (occurring 50 times, since the opponent plays B more often due to a lower payoff for them)
Average payoff from strategy R = (25*45 + 50*0)/75 = 13.33$ per round

Since my opponent's optimal strategy is also to play R, on average, they will earn the same as me when playing against each other. In this case, it seems like both players are indifferent between choosing R or B, but since I can choose first, I would prefer to choose R to ensure a higher chance of earning 45$ per round, even though the overall difference is small compared to my opponent.

In conclusion, as a human player, I would choose R (as in {R}).
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

As a human player, I have already chosen R in the previous round, and my opponent chose B. In this case, I would still stick to my choice of R, since my goal is to maximize my earnings over the long term, and choosing R now does not change the fact that I should play R as my optimal strategy considering the overall payoffs for both strategies.

So, in this round, I will choose R again (as in {R}).
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

As a human player, since both my choice (R) and my opponent's choice (R) resulted in a joint reward of 45$ each, I would continue playing the same strategy to maximize my earnings over the long term.

As an undergraduate student participating in the lab experiment, I would change my strategy to choose B for the next round (as in {B}). This is because my previous choice of R resulted in a loss compared to my opponent's choice of B.

By choosing B now, I can maximize my potential earnings in future rounds since my optimal strategy is to play R most of the time, and by occasionally choosing B when my opponent chooses R, I can take advantage of their suboptimal choice and earn 40$ each time. This will help me minimize losses in the long run and potentially increase my overall earnings.
